content: hi everyone why lock here way back in
episode 10 we made these my original tavern tiles and if you've made some for
yourself you know that they are a pain and not just a pain to do literally they
cause pain like carpal tunnel carving up those popsicle sticks so just like I did
recently for easier dungeon tiles cutting corners and getting 80% the
result with 50% of the effort I thought I'd do the same and look at ways to cut
corners on tavern tiles so let's look at some easier ways to do those tavern
tiles now without a doubt the most painful part was the wooden planks and
texturing them so instead of popsicle sticks we're gonna start with foam this
is extruded polystyrene also known as home insulation available at any home
improvement store I'm gonna mill it down into eighth inch thick sheets using my
proxxon hot wire cutter and then a hair comb you could use a variety of tools
here wire brush is very popular but I'm not so much a fan because the streaks
are too thin these comb tines give a bigger bolder grain so scrape along a
few times at slightly different angles each pass so you get this brush on some
black acrylic for a solid base coat then with burnt umber apply a good over brush
so like 80 90 percent coverage you can see I'm working a bit of paint off the
brush but it's definitely not a dry brush this is meaningful and go with the
grain next up is terracotta use a fairly large brush like one or one and a half
inches and this time go against the grain you can see how much I'm applying
again it's not a dry brush but also not a base coat and I'm doing much less than
the burnt umber a moment ago and the final step with honey brown
another over brush also against the grain and like the terracotta about 50%
coverage so we have these nice veneers made up they don't look super awesome
right now but once we start cutting them into small pieces the effect will hit
home now for the tiles for the foundations no messing around two and a
half inch squares straight up I'm using double corrugated cardboard here but if
you wanted to do the cardboard lock concept from episode 95 you could do
that it's gonna take extra time but given the time savings we're about to
enjoy with the later steps maybe you'll consider that worth the offset up to you
I am NOT making this batch with cardboard lock walls walls are also
double corrugated again because it's a convenient quarter-inch thick gonna cut
half inch wide strips against the corrugation like this and then chop them
to length and hot glue them to the foundation this is why we want those
corrugation tubes exposed because that's a lot of surface area for the hot glue
to sink into very strong connection now pick a beige color
this is folk art linen and base coat the walls you'll probably need two or three
coats once that's dry take some burnt umber and water it way way down to make
a wash and apply that to the wall if it goes on too rich no problem just dip
your brush in the water and then swish it around on the wall to remix and
dilute that paint this is pretty easy to master
here they are all drying next tip we always talk about corrugation cladding
we can get a big-time savings by not having to paint it so here I've bought a
mix pack of brownish beige-ish cardstock 50 sheets for three bucks and that's a
lifetime supply trust me so looking through these colors I picked one of
these dark brown ones measured out lines at quarter inch intervals cut
and hot glue over the corrugation you also get the hang of this pretty quick
oh and one tip if you do have a wall do the wall first and make it so that the
strip goes all the way down onto the foundation then when you wrap the
foundation edge don't overlap that strip do it in multiple pieces otherwise
you'll create a small bulge there at the corner and that's going to create gaps
and your finish tiles later on trust me there are 22 tiles in the trash next to
me right now now take a piece of veneer we prepared and start cutting up the
squares remember just as in episode 10 you need to select an orientation and
always stick to it so that no matter which way the tile is rotated the
checkerboard pattern is still correct so for example when I look at the tile in
front of me I always glue on the lower right square first with its grain
oriented up and down then I do the other three and I forgot to focus the camera
here sorry but when you cut the squares you'll see if there's some newly exposed
foam and that green is sticking out like a sore thumb so we just take a small
brush and touch it up with some burnt umber easy and we're about to go to the
table to see the final product but real quick some reminders if you like what
you're about to see please don't hesitate to hit that like button
subscribe reminders etc etc there is a link in the description below from my
Amazon storefront easy free way to support the channel if you want just buy
your stuff through that link and for all you 3d printers out there while ochs
crafting vids is sponsored by heroes hoard which has an excellent range of
high-quality models including but not limited to Altru tiles lines which are
open lock compatible also check out my modules over on the DMS guild and
remember $3 patrons get free copies of all my releases so here they are side by
side new and old you got a side wall a corner and a field tile the old ones
took I don't even remember how long but these new ones I I knocked out this
entire in that you're about to see in about four hours worth of work of course
depending on your personal tastes you might think that this isn't a compromise
maybe that cobblestone isn't to your fancy after all that that has walls that
don't look like they're the same on both sides so like if you are using it as an
interior wall look out of place over here on the new
style you got that sort of stucco simulated look works inside and outside
you also might consider for the spaces doing three planks of foam instead of a
square again time savings so of course your clip on features that you've made
in the past still fit because they were to a quarter-inch standard that's why
the walls are as thick as they are it's a little sneak peak here of what we're
gonna be doing next time a bunch of different tavern date Corps if you liked
this particular project here's two more that you should go check out right now
also enjoy this month's community showcase and don't forget to subscribe
and click that bell reminder icon I am why lock thanks for joining me and I'll
see you next time
